# LA County Fires Lewis Brisbois Over Racist Emails... From Lawyers Who Left The Firm... That The Firm Disclosed To The Public
## Query: Should the client punish the lawyers' prior firm for this?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 26, 2023 at 5:40 PM
23
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/la-county-fires-lewis-brisbois-over-racist-emails-from-lawyers-who-left-the-firm-that-the-firm-disclosed-to-the-public/&text=LA%20County%20Fires%20Lewis%20Brisbois%20Over%20Racist%20Emails…%20From%20Lawyers%20Who%20Left%20The%20Firm…%20That%20The%20Firm%20Disclosed%20To%20The%20Public)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/la-county-fires-lewis-brisbois-over-racist-emails-from-lawyers-who-left-the-firm-that-the-firm-disclosed-to-the-public/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/la-county-fires-lewis-brisbois-over-racist-emails-from-lawyers-who-left-the-firm-that-the-firm-disclosed-to-the-public/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
According to a [report from Bloomberg](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/bankruptcy-law/la-county-cutting-ties-with-lewis-brisbois-after-racist-emails), Los Angeles County has dumped Lewis Brisbois over [racist, sexist, antisemitic, and all around gross emails](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/barber-ranen-offensive-emails/) exchanged by former Lewis Brisbois partners.

Which got us thinking… is this the right outcome?

After all, the partners at issue have already left Lewis Brisbois, decamping for their own firm which very rapidly [ceased to be their own firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/barber-ranen-daugherty-lordan-new-name/) after [they resigned](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/barber-ranen-resign-racist-sexist-antisemitic-emails/). In fact, this all came to light because Lewis Brisbois released the emails, claiming that they only learned of the emails recently. Assuming that’s true… should Lewis Brisbois be penalized here?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
On the other hand:

“Our office expects that law firms with whom we contract actively promote and practice inclusion, diversity, equity, and anti-racism, and treat everyone in their workforce with dignity and respect,” [LA County Counsel Dawyn Harrison] said. “It is critical that firms handling our most sensitive matters are empathetic to and compassionate toward the constituents we serve,” she said.

The highest levels of the firm might not have known what was going on in this group, but the fact that it happened at all speaks to a breakdown in firm culture. As a client, LA County is distancing itself from a place where emails like these could ever happen.

What is a law firm? If it’s a collection of partner fiefdoms, then the current version of Lewis Brisbois doesn’t have anything to do with what Barber and Ranen did. If it’s a unified entity, then it has to treat oversight of its constituent practice groups seriously and accept responsibility when this happens on its watch. The latter seems like the better model.

# Are Smaller Market Lawyers Actually Better Than Major Market Biglaw Lawyers?
## A new study suggests clients have discovered the value of a smaller market lawyer.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJuly 19, 2018 at 12:06 PM
48
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/are-smaller-market-lawyers-actually-better-than-major-market-biglaw-lawyers/&text=Are%20Smaller%20Market%20Lawyers%20Actually%20Better%20Than%20Major%20Market%20Biglaw%20Lawyers?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/are-smaller-market-lawyers-actually-better-than-major-market-biglaw-lawyers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/07/are-smaller-market-lawyers-actually-better-than-major-market-biglaw-lawyers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The most consistent complaint about Above the Law’s coverage of associate salary increases is our perceived explicit bias against firms fully matching the top-of-market scale in every city across the country. It’s not uncommon to receive two or three irate emails every week calling us out for “disrespecting” the hard-working associates of… some random American city… who are just as smart and capable as any Cravath recruit, all because we’ll say that we don’t really think firms should be paying first-years $190K to live in Charlotte.

And the rub of it is, we’re still right about this. It has nothing to do with the number of hours lawyers put in across the country or even the level of skill out there. Major market attorneys should be paid more because recruiting attorneys to work in these markets has to respect the cost of living issue. Full stop. New York has more open jobs to staff with talented attorneys than Minneapolis and getting lawyers to come to New York and stay here requires more cash.

It’s not disrespect, it’s economics. We still want you to get your due for the work you put in and we consistently note that law school debt respects no geographic boundaries. We just don’t think it’s fair that people toiling away in Midtown to spend 80 percent of their income between debt and rent for the cause of pay parity across markets.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
So while this may not salve anyone still angry over our coverage, those mid-market lawyers should be excited to hear about a new study suggesting that attorneys in smaller cities are not only on par with their major market peers but actually providing superior legal services.

In an article appearing at American Lawyer, AdvanceLaw CEO Michael Williams and managing director Aaron Kotok outline the results of [their study](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/07/18/how-good-are-lawyers-in-mid-market-cities/) of the 40 major metropolitan areas with the most attorneys — 36 domestic, 4 international — and find that clients are more ever so slightly more willing to recommend lawyers in smaller markets than larger ones, citing no real difference in the quality of service, but a major difference in cost and efficiency:

For all the talk about prestige locations and how mega cities attract all the best talent, there is no real performance difference. In fact, as the slight downward slope of the best-fit line shows, the largest cities in the data set have marginally lower performance scores than other locations, though this is not statistically significant. (And again, the result is largely the same across various client-service metrics.)

Great news for smaller market lawyers. One has to imagine this trend toward service parity is in no small part due to upward pressure on salaries throughout the country, prompting more and more elite law school graduates every year to say, “wait a minute, perhaps I don’t have to live in a studio with 3 roommates?” But there’s more than a recruiting coup or two at play here. Technological advancements have given firms the opportunity to keep pace with their more staid competitors and the explosion of startups in smaller markets has created more demand — and therefore more opportunities to garner experience — for local players. Add in the fact that national megafirms are increasingly [bringing name-brand practices to smaller markets](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/how-global-biglaw-titans-are-demolishing-local-firms-and-how-to-survive-the-onslaught/) and the reasons why clients are increasingly happy with their smaller town lawyers become pretty clear.

And, before you ask, the authors did check the substance of the work involved and these smaller market teams were receiving “significant high-stakes work.”

That said, the authors do note some important caveats. The highest in finance work flows to New York because that’s where centuries of combined expertise choose to practice. The same can be said of government work heading to Washington:

Note that we are not saying there isn’t an incredible amount of elite legal talent in the largest cities that should be tapped—there is. Likewise, we are not saying that clients can or should send all their work to the so-called “mid-to-large” cities—there are obvious limits to this. But we are saying GCs and their teams should resist defaulting to the usual locations out of habit or history. The data suggests there is a major opportunity here, under current market conditions, to get great talent at lower cost, working extra efficiently.

The crux of all this is that clients need to embrace labor arbitrage. If your company has a matter that can be handled out of Portland, go ahead and handle it out of Portland. The old adage is that no one is going to fire you for hiring Cravath, but that sort of “management from fear” is what rightly gets NFL coaches fired for kicking field goals from the one. Get sophisticated in your vetting and start taking advantage of the quality lawyers in small markets.

Until they give all their associates New York scale and evaporate all their cost edge that is.

Posted at [10:48 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72108) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Law Firm Not Liable for $1.5B Loan Gaffe”: Lorraine Bailey of Courthouse News Service has [an article](https://www.courthousenews.com/law-firm-not-liable-1-5b-loan-gaffe/) that begins, “Entities that lent General Motors $1.5 billion before it went bankrupt cannot sue GM’s law firm, Mayer Brown, for accidentally cancelling the collateral on the loan, the Seventh Circuit ruled.”

You can access yesterday’s ruling of a unanimous three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit](http://www.ca7.uscourts.gov) at [this link](http://media.ca7.uscourts.gov/cgi-bin/rssExec.pl?Submit=Display&Path=Y2017/D06-28/C:16-2983:J:Hamilton:aut:T:fnOp:N:1986869:S:0).

Posted at [10:44 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72107) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Notre Dame prof, an appeals court nominee, deserves support”: Law professor [Jennifer Mason McAward](http://law.nd.edu/directory/jennifer-mason-mcaward/) has [this essay](http://www.southbendtribune.com/news/opinion/viewpoint/viewpoint-notre-dame-prof-an-appeals-court-nominee-deserves-support/article_dad923a9-d0a1-5656-a87c-b48787376bb1.html) online at The South Bend Tribune.

Posted at [12:50 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72106) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Trump’s judicial nominee from Louisville ducks questions about his controversial blog posts”: Andrew Wolfson of The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Kentucky has [this report](http://www.courier-journal.com/story/news/2017/06/28/judicial-nominee-louisville-john-k-bush-ducks-questions-controversial-blog-posts/433160001/).

Posted at [12:48 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72105) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“11th Circ. OKs Search By Disguised Officers In Fraud Case”: Steven Trader of Law360.com has [this report](https://www.law360.com/articles/939475/11th-circ-oks-search-by-disguised-officers-in-fraud-case) (subscription required for full access) on [a ruling](http://media.ca11.uscourts.gov/opinions/pub/files/201515023.pdf) that a divided three-judge panel of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit](http://www.ca11.uscourts.gov) issued on Wednesday.

Posted at [12:40 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72104) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Appeals court lifts Ohio executions injunction”: Jim Provance of The Toledo Blade has [this report](http://www.toledoblade.com/State/2017/06/28/Court-lifts-injunction-against-Ohio-executions.html).

Eric Heisig of The Cleveland Plain Dealer reports that “[Ohio can use three-drug combination to resume executing those on death row, appeals court says](http://www.cleveland.com/court-justice/index.ssf/2017/06/ohio_can_use_three-drug_cockta.html).”

Alan Johnson of The Columbus Dispatch reports that “[US Supreme Court will be asked to halt Ohio executions](http://www.dispatch.com/news/20170628/us-supreme-court-will-be-asked-to-halt-ohio-executions).”

Lisa Cornwell and Kantele Franko of The Associated Press report that “[Appeals court ruling opens door to Ohio resuming executions](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_DEATH_PENALTY_OHIO?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).”

And Chris Kenning of Reuters reports that “[U.S. appeals court lifts injunction against Ohio executions](https://www.reuters.com/article/ohio-execution-idUSL1N1JP1SQ).”

You can access Wednesday’s 8-to-6 en banc ruling of the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit](http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov) at [this link](http://www.opn.ca6.uscourts.gov/opinions.pdf/17a0136p-06.pdf).

Posted at [12:18 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72103) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Arrest made after Ten Commandments monument at Arkansas Capitol toppled, shattered”: Emma Pettit of The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette has [this report](http://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2017/jun/28/ten-commandments-monument-arkansas-capitol-toppled/).

And Steve Barnes of Reuters reports that “[Man smashes Arkansas Capitol’s new Ten Commandments monument](https://www.reuters.com/article/us-arkansas-commandments-idUSKBN19J1XX).”

Posted at [12:03 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/06/29/#72102) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# Biglaw Firm Takes On The IRS
## Just as the IRS is turning its enforcement efforts to partnerships....
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 21, 2024 at 12:16 PMMarch 21, 2024 at 11:21 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firm-takes-on-the-irs/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Takes%20On%20The%20IRS)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firm-takes-on-the-irs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-firm-takes-on-the-irs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In one corner, we have one of the largest law firms in the world, with 4,800 attorneys, the firm that puts the Big in Biglaw, taking down more than $3.3 billion in revenue: Baker McKenzie! In the other, we have a 161-year-old federal agency, with a $14.3 billion budget, and able to strike fear into the hearts of the likes of Al Capone: the IRS! Who will win this battle of the titans?

Earlier this week, Baker McKenzie sued the Internal Revenue Service in[ federal court ](https://fingfx.thomsonreuters.com/gfx/legaldocs/zjpqwdrampx/Clarke%20v%20IRS%20-%20DCD%20-%2020240318.pdf)under the Freedom of Information Act. The plaintiff is the head of the firm’s North America tax dispute group, [George Clarke](https://www.bakermckenzie.com/en/people/c/clarke-george-m), and the suit alleges the agency failed to disclose memos, policy statements, and training materials related to their increased focus and audits on partnerships and other pass-through entities. One example of[ the materials sought ](https://www.abajournal.com/news/article/baker-mckenzie-partner-sues-irs-for-disclosure-of-partnership-audit-strategies)is a paper discussed by an IRS employee at a November 2023 ABA Section of Taxation conference, which was described in a write-up on the event as “IRS Taking Partnership Audits to New Level.”

Hmmmm, I wonder why a Biglaw PARTNER would be interested in the IRS’s enforcement of PARTNERSHIP agreements…. Oh, and I guess Clarke also said in the complaint, he wants “to learn more about the Internal Revenue Service’s practices so that I can better represent my clients.” Which, you know, also sounds pretty necessary for his job.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The heat is already on for partnerships. The IRS has already[ reportedly](https://www.reuters.com/legal/litigation/law-firm-baker-mckenzie-sues-irs-details-partnership-tax-crackdown-2024-03-19/) opened up 75 examinations on large partnerships including hedge funds, real estate investment partnerships, and… law firms. The IRS also plans to send compliance letters to an additional 500 partnerships.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon [@Kathryn1@mastodon.social.](//mastodon.social/@Kathryn1%22)

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 04.26.17
## * Can you hear me now? Modern marvels of technology like cellphones and other electronic devices are barred from the Supreme Court during oral arguments, but yesterday, justice was interrupted by the ringing of... a Justice's cellphone. Who was the culprit? The offending phone belonged to Justice Stephen Breyer. Oopsie! [[AP](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPREME_COURT_CELLPHONE?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT)] * After a week charged with sexual harassment allegations and the ouster of Bill O'Reilly, just when Fox News thought its troubles were over, a group of current and former employees filed a class-action lawsuit against the network alleging "abhorrent, intolerable, unlawful and hostile racial discrimination." The plaintiffs' lawyers got in this zinger of a statement: "When it comes to racial discrimination, 21st Century Fox has been operating as if it should be called 18th Century Fox." [[DealBook / New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/25/business/media/fox-news-racial-discrimination-lawsuit.html)] * Ever since it dumped Eversheds, Milwaukee-based Foley & Lardner has been out on the prowl for another merger partner, and it looks like the firm has finally found its ideal mate in New York boutique Friedman Kaplan Seiler & Adelman. The whole thing seems to be a bit "incestuous" if you ask us. We'll have more on this later today. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784349808/Foley--Lardner-Explores-Union-With-New-Yorks-Friedman-Kaplan)] * Ahead of his confirmation hearing todays, Makan Delrahim, President Donald Trump's nominee to lead the antitrust division of the Department of Justice who's been called a "centrist nominee," has pledged to recuse himself from all matters involving his prior work as a lobbyist, including the merger between Anthem and Cigna. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/justice-antitrust-pick-pledges-anthem-recusal-ahead-of-hearing/)] * At some firms, like Ballard Spahr, senior partners must "transition[] their practices" by age 60, but at other firms, like Cozen O'Connor, age is nothing but a number. "We have so many lawyers who are extremely productive and terrific lawyers and if they want to work well into their 70s, God bless 'em," says CEO Michael Heller. [[Philly Inquirer](http://www.philly.com/philly/columnists/chris-mondics/How-law-firms-manage-the-retirement-of-senior-partners-dechert-cozen-Ballard-Spahr.html?mobi=true)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 26, 2017 at 8:59 AMApril 25, 2017 at 9:36 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/morning-docket-04-26-17/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2004.26.17)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/morning-docket-04-26-17/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/04/morning-docket-04-26-17/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Turn off your phone, silly!

* Can you hear me now? Modern marvels of technology like cellphones and other electronic devices are barred from the Supreme Court during oral arguments, but yesterday, justice was interrupted by the ringing of… a Justice’s cellphone. Who was the culprit? The offending phone belonged to Justice Stephen Breyer. Oopsie! [[AP](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SUPREME_COURT_CELLPHONE?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT)]

* After a week charged with sexual harassment allegations and the ouster of Bill O’Reilly, just when Fox News thought its troubles were over, a group of current and former employees filed a class-action lawsuit against the network alleging “abhorrent, intolerable, unlawful and hostile racial discrimination.” The plaintiffs’ lawyers got in this zinger of a statement: “When it comes to racial discrimination, 21st Century Fox has been operating as if it should be called 18th Century Fox.” [[DealBook / New York Times](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/25/business/media/fox-news-racial-discrimination-lawsuit.html)]

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  

* Ever since it dumped Eversheds, Milwaukee-based Foley & Lardner has been out on the prowl for another merger partner, and it looks like the firm has finally found its ideal mate in New York boutique Friedman Kaplan Seiler & Adelman. The whole thing seems to be a bit “incestuous” if you ask us. We’ll have more on this later today. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202784349808/Foley--Lardner-Explores-Union-With-New-Yorks-Friedman-Kaplan)]

* Ahead of his confirmation hearing todays, Makan Delrahim, President Donald Trump’s nominee to lead the antitrust division of the Department of Justice who’s been called a “centrist nominee,” has pledged to recuse himself from all matters involving his prior work as a lobbyist, including the merger between Anthem and Cigna. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/justice-antitrust-pick-pledges-anthem-recusal-ahead-of-hearing/)]

* At some firms, like Ballard Spahr, senior partners must “transition[] their practices” by age 60, but at other firms, like Cozen O’Connor, age is nothing but a number. “We have so many lawyers who are extremely productive and terrific lawyers and if they want to work well into their 70s, God bless ’em,” says CEO Michael Heller. [[Philly Inquirer](http://www.philly.com/philly/columnists/chris-mondics/How-law-firms-manage-the-retirement-of-senior-partners-dechert-cozen-Ballard-Spahr.html?mobi=true)]

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. # For Some, Getting Laid Off May Yield Financial Benefits
## Before I get trolled on the internet for seemingly not understanding the pain of layoffs ...
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onDecember 9, 2022 at 2:31 PMDecember 9, 2022 at 3:16 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/for-some-getting-laid-off-may-yield-financial-benefits/&text=For%20Some,%20Getting%20Laid%20Off%20May%20Yield%20Financial%20Benefits)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/for-some-getting-laid-off-may-yield-financial-benefits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/for-some-getting-laid-off-may-yield-financial-benefits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It appears as if some law firms have begun mass layoffs as law firm managers expect an upcoming recession and shops experience various economic pressures. Of course, getting laid off is a very traumatic experience for the people who are laid off, for those who remain at firms, and for the individuals who have to terminate workers. I know from firsthand experience how getting laid off stinks; I was laid off from a job at the beginning of my career. Before I get trolled on the internet for seemingly not understanding the pain of layoffs, let me be extremely clear that for many people, getting terminated from a job is one of the worst things that can happen. I have incredible sympathy for people who are laid off, and I vividly remember the sleepless nights and shame I felt at being laid off myself. However, in certain situations, getting laid off can have some benefits and can even help people achieve certain financial goals.

Many lawyers and staff who are laid off receive severance payments to help them during their transition to a new job. In the legal industry, employees commonly receive three to six months of severance payments during which they are still on the payroll of their old firms receiving pay. Even if the worker finds a new job, they are typically entitled to such payments, and workers will essentially earn two salaries while they are working at another job and receiving severance payments. Moreover, in some states, workers are sometimes entitled to unemployment benefits even though they receive severance payments.

The total amount of severance payments someone receives can be substantial. Indeed, some attorneys may receive six figures worth of severance payments. Of course, severance payments are usually taxed just like all other wages, so a sizable chunk of this money goes to the tax man. However, this still leaves a substantial amount of money in the pockets of those who are laid off. If individuals have a plan, they can use their severance payments to accomplish a number of goals.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
For instance, after someone gets laid off, they may qualify for unemployment benefits. If that worker subsists on unemployment benefits (which might be difficult since the benefits are usually nowhere near a person’s salary) they can pocket all of the money they receive in severance. If that person is able to find a new job in a month or two, they will stop receiving unemployment benefits if they received it while getting severance, and then they will effectively earn two salaries. So long as people do not burn through the extra money, they should be able to use these funds to pay down student loans, save for a down payment on a home, or achieve a number of other financial goals.

From my own experience, getting laid off and receiving severance had a positive financial impact on my own life. I am fortunate to live in a state that permits workers to receive unemployment benefits while also receiving severance payments in most circumstances. At the time I was laid off from my job earlier in my career, I lived on a shoestring budget, and I was basically able to cover all of my expenses on my unemployment benefits alone. Of course, I had to be creative and not splurge on anything big, but I was basically able to pocket all of my severance payments.

I was able to find a new job only a few months after I was laid off, well within the timeframe that I was entitled to unemployment benefits. The new job paid less, but I was still comfortable with the income, and after the end of the year, I received a huge tax refund since my severance payments included withholding for my old salary and were not based on my new income.

Even after paying taxes on my severance payments, I had a substantial amount of money that I completely poured on my student loans. I think that I was able to pay off a third of my remaining student loans with the severance payments I had saved up, and with this high-interest debt gone, my student loans became much more manageable. I do not think that I would have been able to pay off all of my student loans by the age of 30, which was a long-time goal, if I had not been laid off and given severance payments.

All told, again, being laid off is a traumatic experience, and my months between jobs were filled with restless nights, feelings of shame, and a host of other issues. In addition, some terminated workers do not receive severance payments. However, if you worked at a law firm that provides severance, and you are financially responsible, getting laid off can sometimes lead to some positive financial outcomes.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. You can reach Jordan through email at [jordan@rothmanlawyer.com](mailto:jordan@rothmanlawyer.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

# How Do You Avoid The Stress Of A Biglaw Job?
## In-house columnist Mark Herrmann, who was a partner at a Biglaw firm for nearly two decades, explains how to minimize the pressure of Biglaw life.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onApril 30, 2018 at 10:03 AMApril 30, 2018 at 9:55 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/how-do-you-avoid-the-stress-of-a-biglaw-job/&text=How%20Do%20You%20Avoid%20The%20Stress%20Of%20A%20Biglaw%20Job?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/how-do-you-avoid-the-stress-of-a-biglaw-job/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/how-do-you-avoid-the-stress-of-a-biglaw-job/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I recently blew the dust off the “book talk” that I give about [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) (affiliate link) and delivered the talk to a group of international law students here in London.

I predictably get very different reactions when I give the talk to different groups.  Partners think the talk’s a riot.  They laugh out loud when I’m speaking.  I have to wait for the laughter to die down before I can go on to the next sentence.  “You’ve been a fly on the wall of my office for the last 20 years!  How’d you know?”

Associates don’t laugh as much.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
And then there are law students.

When my daughter was six years old, and all of her classmates were losing their baby teeth, I held up one of her arms and felt around in her armpit:  “Have any of your classmates lost their baby arms yet?”

She gave me a look that said, “I’m pretty sure that he’s kidding.  But, if he’s not, this is really gonna suck.”

That’s how law students typically respond to my Curmudgeon talk:  “I’m pretty sure that he’s kidding.  But, if he’s not, this is really gonna suck.”

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Anyway, during the question and answer period at the end of my recent talk, one student asked a very Millennial question:  “Do you have any ideas for how you can avoid the stress of working at a Biglaw firm?”

Sure I do.

In fact, in a sense, my entire book is aimed at that question.  When the book first came out, my mother-in-law told me that, “Some people who read this book will love what they read and decide to go to law school.  Others will hate what they read and choose not to go to law school.  And you’ve probably done a service either way.”

I hope so.

My mother-in-law’s language was actually imprecise:  Curmudgeon isn’t really about going to law school.  It’s more about how to succeed in a Biglaw firm.  (I was a partner in one of those puppies for 17 years.)  But you get the drift.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
And that answers the question posed by the law student in my audience:  How do you avoid the stress of working at a Biglaw firm?  Don’t work for a Biglaw firm, of course.

No one says you have to.  And you may hate it.  So don’t do it.

Some people read about the Biglaw environment and love it:  Intense pressure.  A real desire to create error-free perfection.  Hard thinking about tough issues.  Constant deadlines, and long (and unpredictable) hours to meet them.  No praise. 

Sounds great!

Other people read those same words and are nauseated.

Why would anyone choose to do that with their life?

So:  If you don’t like it, don’t do it.  Do trusts and estates work at a small firm.  Go in-house.  Teach.  Many (indeed, the vast majority of) career paths in the law do not involve working at a big firm.  There’s no shame in taking another route.

I suppose my only advice for reducing pressure if you do choose to work at a big firm is this:  Don’t put pressure on yourself unnecessarily.  When a big case settles after you’ve been working on it for three years, there’s going to be a gap in your schedule.  Don’t continue to show up at the office just for the sake of showing up.  This is one of those rare moments when you’ll get to relax.  So do.  When the pressure’s off, wallow in its absence.

And remember that life isn’t really that hard:  You’ll never lose your baby arms.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# New York Mainstay Biglaw Firm Announces Bonuses
## Another firm shows they have the cash to keep up.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 12, 2019 at 6:10 PMNovember 12, 2019 at 6:11 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/new-york-mainstay-biglaw-firm-announces-bonuses/&text=New%20York%20Mainstay%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Announces%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/new-york-mainstay-biglaw-firm-announces-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/new-york-mainstay-biglaw-firm-announces-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Milbank [opened the dam](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/breaking-biglaw-bonuses-are-here/), then Cravath[ seconded that bonus scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/cravath-announces-bonuses-now-the-2019-bonus-season-can-really-begin/). Now it’s a free for all as the elite Biglaw firms are throwing around cash to show they have the pocketbooks big enough to match.

The latest firm to announce bonuses is Cleary Gottlieb Steen & Hamilton. This afternoon, the  venerable firm sent around a memo announcing the expected match of market bonuses. I guess they’re particularly eager to show the [recent partner defections](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/major-lateral-moves-its-open-season-on-cleary-partners/) won’t be having a negative impact on the firm’s prospects.

For those that need the reminder the scale is as follows:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Class of 2019 – $15,000 (pro-rated)
Class of 2018 – $15,000
Class of 2017 – $25,000
Class of 2016 – $50,000
Class of 2015 – $65,000
Class of 2014 – $80,000
Class of 2013 – $90,000
Class of 2012 – $100,000
Class of 2011+ – $100,000

Bonuses will be paid by the firm on December 13th. ([Full memo on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/11/new-york-mainstay-biglaw-firm-announces-bonuses/2/))

Remember, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for all salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

# Baking Up Some Delicious Raises
## After cutting back last year, the firm is moving ahead with the rest of Biglaw.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 18, 2021 at 1:31 PMJune 18, 2021 at 12:44 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/baker-botts-raises-21/&text=Baking%20Up%20Some%20Delicious%20Raises)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/baker-botts-raises-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/baker-botts-raises-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
No word from the butcher or the candlestick maker, but these Baker Botts associates are pleased today to learn the firm will be joining the Biglaw salary tidal wave with a DPW match (I’m going to start using that terminology instead of “full” to differentiate between the firms offering either $205K for the class of 21 or $375K for the class of 12).

Baker Botts was one of the [early adopters of COVID cuts](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/baker-botts-cuts/), pulling back salaries across the board to deal with the pandemic. It left a bitter taste with a lot of attorney tipsters. But since 2020 ended up being an incredibly lucrative year for Biglaw, it’s good to see the firm reflect the good times.



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Effective July 1 and including a summer associate bump. As per standard Biglaw operating procedure, counsel are shunted off into “communicated individually” limbo. It’s hard to get info on counsel because, at many firms, sharing their individual details with us might out them as a source. But it would be nice if folks could share broadly what they’re making after this round of raises so we can ballpark the market.

You can check out the [full memo here](https://abovethelaw.com/uploads/2021/06/Baker-Botts.pdf).

Please help us help you when it comes to salary news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Salary) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Salary”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Are You There Cravath? It's Me, Milbank.
## Where this raise goes from here is in one firm's hands.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 6, 2018 at 9:34 AM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/are-you-there-cravath-its-me-milbank/&text=Are%20You%20There%20Cravath?%20It’s%20Me,%20Milbank.)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/are-you-there-cravath-its-me-milbank/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/are-you-there-cravath-its-me-milbank/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Listen, [Milbank’s done everything it can](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/) from its own, vulnerable position.

It stuck its neck out there as the firm willing to embrace a cost of living increase for its associates and only [Proskauer](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-first-biglaw-firm-to-match-the-new-associate-raises/) and [Winston](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/let-the-salary-wars-commence-another-biglaw-firm-has-matched-the-190k-scale/) — another pair of powerful but not quite elite players — have matched. (And litigation boutique [Hueston Hennigan,](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-first-firm-has-matched-the-new-milbank-scale/) but no one is looking to them to set the market rate.)

The silence from the rest of the field can only be chalked up to the industry’s cartel-ish impulse to follow Cravath’s lead in all things compensation. There’s a somewhat cynical view circulating in Biglaw that Proskauer and Winston moved when they did in a desperate bid to set the market before Cravath goes over the top and creates a $200K scale.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
But will they? We’re just in this eerie holding pattern right now, waiting on Cravath to set the market. No one seriously believes Proskauer is going to be paying associates more than Cravath in New York when it comes time for on-campus interviews. So Cravath has to at least match… but if that’s the plan, why have they kept mum for two days?

Right now, the whole industry seems to be waiting on Cravath to make the call. Will this round of salary wars be the modest cost of living adjustment that [every firm should join](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/why-the-milbank-raise-is-not-that-big-of-a-deal-and-why-it-is/) or the start of the market fragmentation that Cravath thought it was buying two years ago?

The legal world is waiting.

# Top 50 Am Law Firm Announces Reduction In Force, Will Cut 6% Of Global Workforce
## The firm is also deferring its incoming associates.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 13, 2023 at 1:30 PMJune 13, 2023 at 2:10 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/orrick-layoffs-deferral/&text=Top%2050%20Am%20Law%20Firm%20Announces%20Reduction%20In%20Force,%20Will%20Cut%206%%20Of%20Global%20Workforce)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/orrick-layoffs-deferral/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/orrick-layoffs-deferral/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Layoffs and deferrals within Biglaw are far from over.

The leaders of Orrick — a firm that brought in $1,379,702,000 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 32 on the most recent Am Law 100 ranking — just announced a global reduction in force. It seems that about 6% of the firm’s workforce, including attorneys and staff members, will be let go.

When reached for comment, a spokesperson from Orrick offered this statement on the firm’s behalf:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“The action is a response to a convergence of market forces: reduced client demand in some areas related to market uncertainty and the impact of technology, data and the evolving workplace on the type of support we need to serve our clients and operate our firm.

Affected colleagues have contributed meaningfully to our firm — this is not a reflection on any individual — and we will support them with a transition package.”

As noted by the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2023/06/13/orrick-lays-off-attorneys-and-staff-defers-incoming-class/), it’s estimated that the firm’s cuts will affect about 40 associates and 50 staff members, with a greater impact on the firm’s corporate transactional teams. Orrick will be offering a benefits package to those impacted, including salary, COBRA reimbursement, outplacement services, and wellness resources. “We believe this action is the most fair and transparent way to advance our strategy and ensure we have ample work opportunities for our team,” Orrick’s spokesperson said.

On top of today’s reduction in force, the firm is also deferring its incoming associate class to January 16, 2024. Orrick is now the fourth firm to delay the start date for its entry-level associates. Affected first-years will receive a stipend of $15,000, as well as an additional stipend to purchase health insurance and early access to the firm’s wellness resources.

Best of luck to those who are being let go or deferred from Orrick.

# Lawyers Shouldn't Get Too Emotional When Representing Friends And Family
## Lawyers are usually able to provide the best legal services possible when they are objective and are governed by reason and not by emotion. Then family comes along ...
By [Jordan Rothman](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jordanrothman/)  
onJune 17, 2022 at 4:46 PMJune 17, 2022 at 2:07 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/lawyers-shouldnt-get-too-emotional-when-representing-friends-and-family/&text=Lawyers%20Shouldn’t%20Get%20Too%20Emotional%20When%20Representing%20Friends%20And%20Family)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/lawyers-shouldnt-get-too-emotional-when-representing-friends-and-family/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/lawyers-shouldnt-get-too-emotional-when-representing-friends-and-family/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Would a relative charge for legal services? Did we charge Two Slices of Pie Lawyer over there for this lovely meal that we’re all enjoying despite that lawsuit? (Image via Getty)

Every lawyer at some point in their career has likely been asked to perform legal work for friends or family members. Most of the time, friends or relatives just have a quick legal question that does not require too much time or effort. Other times, family and friends may have a full-blown legal matter for which they need to retain counsel, and these matters can often get heated. Although it is easy to let tensions rise when representing family and friends, lawyers should try their best not to get too emotional since this could cloud their judgment and negatively impact a representation.

The first time I ever represented a close family friend was early in my career when I was working for a midsized regional firm. A close family friend and his children, who were also friends with my family, owned a company that was being sued in an emergent matter that needed to be decided on an expedited basis. The outcome of this matter could have had a substantial impact on this family’s business, and I knew the pressure was on to get the best result possible for my client.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
I worked extremely hard for my family friends and put in numerous hours during nights and weekends to crank out solid work product on an expedited basis. Within a few weeks of accepting this matter, we needed to go to court for an order to show cause hearing, and my client wanted to appear at the hearing to see that everyone was going well in court. When I met the client in court, I could tell that this family friend was weary from this matter, and it was tough to see him seem tired by all of the legal hurdles he needed to face.

I was extremely animated in court and was not as amicable as usual with my adversary because of the tension that my client was facing because of this lawsuit. This could have made it harder to reach a resolution with my adversary since it is usually best to have a solid relationship with an adversary so that deals can be struck to avoid parts of the litigation process. In the end, I was able to obtain a very favorable result for my client, but after some reflection, it was obvious that I let emotions related to representing a close family friend get to me during the representation.

At another time in my legal career, I had to represent some of my relatives who were being threatened with a (no pun intended) relatively meritless lawsuit. There was a release that clearly precluded the claimant from pursuing the claim, but the claimant’s lawyer made all kinds of threats against my relatives, likely in order to use aggression to shake us down for some quick money. As negotiations got more heated, the other lawyer started threatening me by saying that he would subpoena various family members and make their lives miserable if we did not settle his client’s claim.

It was difficult not to get too passionate about this situation. The lawyer was threatening people who were very near and dear to me, and the thought of my relatives being faced with the stress of litigation did not sit well with me. To some extent, the passion helped me out in the representation. I was able to channel some of the anger of this annoyance in communications with my adversary, and this likely helped me resolve the matter at minimal cost to my relatives. But my judgment was definitely clouded by the passion of representing family, and this could have negatively impacted the services I rendered.

Lawyers are usually able to provide the best legal services possible when they are objective and are governed by reason and not by emotion. In many situations, lawyers need to be the voice of reason while clients are the ones who make decisions out of passion and emotions. Lawyers need to be able to objectively size up the merits of a case and whether claims and defenses will succeed in court. In addition, lawyers need to be able to accurately evaluate the value of a case when it is time to settle a matter. When lawyers act emotionally, there may not be a core of reason guiding a representation and ensuring that strategies are based on what objectively is positive for a representation and not what is governed by emotion. In certain situations, representing family may even be unethical since the representation might be materially limited by the circumstances of the case.

All told, friends and family members often turn to lawyers they know in order to handle their legal work since they naturally trust a lawyer who is close to them than other attorneys. Lawyers should not let emotions get the best of them during such representations to ensure their friends and relatives get the best representation possible.

Jordan Rothman is a partner of [The Rothman Law Firm](http://www.rothmanlawyer.com/), a full-service New York and New Jersey law firm. He is also the founder of [Student Debt Diaries](https://studentdebtdiaries.com/), a website discussing how he paid off his student loans. # What Millennial Lawyers Want From Their Careers
## A majority would trade compensation for more time off.
By [Vera Djordjevich](https://abovethelaw.com/author/vdjordjevich/)  
onApril 27, 2023 at 12:48 PMApril 27, 2023 at 12:05 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/millennial-lawyers-careers/&text=What%20Millennial%20Lawyers%20Want%20From%20Their%20Careers)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/millennial-lawyers-careers/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/04/millennial-lawyers-careers/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Work-life balance and remote work policies have become rallying cries among many young attorneys in the last few years, and a recent ATL survey bears out the importance of these elements in today’s workplaces.

In the [latest of our series of millennial surveys](https://info.abovethelaw.com/searching-for-balance-millennial-lawyers-perspectives-on-the-legal-industry) conducted with Major, Lindsey & Africa, we asked lawyers about dozens of topics, including their priorities, career aspirations, and perspectives on law firm culture. According to the respondents, most of whom work in Biglaw, the two most important factors when evaluating a potential employer are compensation and work-life balance. 

At the same time, over half of the lawyers surveyed said they would trade compensation for more time off or reduced billable hours. And nearly everyone — almost 90 percent of respondents — would like to work from home at least a few days a week. Although more associates than partners expressed a desire to work remotely full-time, 84 percent of partners said they want to work from home at least part of the time.

In fact, with respect to work-from-home policies, the gender disparities are more striking than those based on the attorneys’ positions. Almost 30 percent of women would like to work entirely from home; among men, the most common preference was two remote days per week. Twenty percent of male respondents said they would prefer to work full-time in the office, compared to just 6 percent of female respondents. 



The survey, which received more than 1,500 responses, underscores other differences based on gender, race, position, or generation — while also revealing areas in which lawyers were largely unified in their views.

For more insights and a detailed look at the survey results, download a[ free copy of the report](https://info.abovethelaw.com/searching-for-balance-millennial-lawyers-perspectives-on-the-legal-industry).

# Morning Docket: 12.16.16
## * Are conservative partners giving smaller bonuses to female associates? Per the results of a recent study, political ideology impacts how partners allocate discretionary income to associates based on gender. If you thought this couldn't happen in Biglaw since bonuses are largely lockstep by class year, think again. The firm studied has 1,000+ lawyers. We'll have more on this later. [[Am Law Daily](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202774850941/Its-True-Republican-Partners-Give-Female-Associates-Smaller-Bonuses?mcode=0&curindex=0&curpage=ALL)] * "We’ve got one of the country’s finest jurists, who I happened to have nominated to the Supreme Court and who’s going to continue to serve our country with distinction as the chief judge on the D.C. circuit, Merrick Garland is here." President Obama hasn't withdrawn his SCOTUS nomination, but his White House Hanukkah party introduction of the jurist indicates he's all but given up on Garland's confirmation. [[Washington Post](https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2016/12/14/is-obama-throwing-in-the-towel-on-merrick-garland/?utm_term=.6bff60d48c23)] * "Just because you didn’t go to law school doesn’t mean you shouldn’t have more time to bond with a new child." Lowenstein Sandler has adopted a gender-neutral family leave policy that's being offered to all of the firm's employees -- not just its lawyers. Congrats to the firm on taking an important leap towards parental equality. [[Big Law Business](https://bol.bna.com/law-firm-adopts-gender-neutral-family-leave-policy/)] * According to the latest ABA data, first-year law school enrollment has increased for the first time since 2010. Don't get too excited over this news, because only 36 more 1Ls were enrolled in law school in 2016 compared to 2015, and one of the schools with the largest enrollment increase ([Indiana Tech](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/indiana-tech-law-school-to-close-citing-20-million-in-losses/)) is closing for good. [[National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/id=1202774844249/Number-of-Students-Enrolling-in-Law-School-Basically-Flat?mcode=1202617074964&curindex=1&curpage=ALL)] * "Once again, public schools have decided that their commitment to diversity does not extend to Christians." Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton is going to war over a religious Charlie Brown Christmas poster that was banned from a local middle school. AG Paxton has filed suit, but some say he did so as a distraction from his own indictment. [[Reuters](http://reuters.com/article/USLegal/idUSL1N1EA272?il=0)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 16, 2016 at 8:59 AMDecember 16, 2016 at 9:00 AM
1

# Biglaw Attorney Benchslapped Over 'Hubris,' Told To Open Checkbook To Personally Pay
## Benchslaps 'live forever on the Internet.'
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 9, 2022 at 12:12 PMAugust 10, 2022 at 10:20 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-attorney-benchslapped-over-hubris-told-to-open-checkbook-to-personally-pay/&text=Biglaw%20Attorney%20Benchslapped%20Over%20‘Hubris,’%20Told%20To%20Open%20Checkbook%20To%20Personally%20Pay)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-attorney-benchslapped-over-hubris-told-to-open-checkbook-to-personally-pay/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/biglaw-attorney-benchslapped-over-hubris-told-to-open-checkbook-to-personally-pay/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Oof, this has got to sting.

No one *likes* being benchslapped by a federal court, but getting called on the carpet for your “hubris and disregard of procedural rules” and ordered to “personally pay” opposing counsel costs? That’s… no bueno.

But that’s exactly what happened to Cooley attorney[ Jon Graves](https://www.cooley.com/people/jon-graves). Eastern District of Pennsylvania Judge Michael M. Baylson[ did not take kindly](https://assets.law360news.com/1518000/1518288/https-ecf-paed-uscourts-gov-doc1-153120551536.pdf) to Graves’s behavior in his representation of Medical Technology Associates in a case against former top executive Carl W. Rausch. Specifically, the judge was peeved over his filing of 61 pages of evidence, after discovery deadlines.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
As [reported by](https://www.law360.com/articles/1518288) Law360:

Graves was ordered to “personally pay” the lawyer representing Rausch and his company for all the legal fees incurred following Graves’ decision in May to file “a 61-page ‘submission’ that included 7 pages of legal argument, citing testimony and documents, and ten exhibits.”

Discovery had already ended in the case. None of the filings were presented during depositions in the case and Rausch’s lawyer called the move a blatant attempt “to evade the page limits set by this court.”

And he’s also headed to extra CLE classes:

“The court orders Mr. Graves to attend six hours of continuing legal education courses on the subject of federal practice and procedure, to be completed within six months of this decision,” Judge Baylson added in his ruling on the matter. Graves would have to submit “certificates of attendance for each course, to include the name of the course, sponsoring organization(s), date of attendance, and length.”

And the the judge reminded Graves there’re more consequences he can dish out, noting, “Furthermore, Mr. Graves is reminded that appearing pro hac vice is a privilege.” And even though Graves’s client has “filed for bankruptcy,” that “does not prevent this court from imposing sanctions for prior conduct of counsel.”

In opposing any sanctions, Graves hired ethics expert Gregory P. Joseph, who wrote:

“In light of the damaging effects sanctions would have on a lawyer with no history of sanctionable conduct, in my opinion, to a reasonable degree of certainty, the court should decline to impose sanctions of any sort on him, his law firm, or his client,” Joseph had implored. “Sanctions of any sort imposed on a lawyer are devastating. They live forever on the Internet.”

Awww, that sure feels like [an Above the Law ](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/benchslap/)shout-out.

# Scheduling A Meeting When You Have Nothing To Say
## The desire to set a cadence means, I fear, that people frequently set meetings for no reason at all.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onJune 1, 2020 at 11:18 AMJune 1, 2020 at 11:24 AM
5
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/scheduling-a-meeting-when-you-have-nothing-to-say/&text=Scheduling%20A%20Meeting%20When%20You%20Have%20Nothing%20To%20Say)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/scheduling-a-meeting-when-you-have-nothing-to-say/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/scheduling-a-meeting-when-you-have-nothing-to-say/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
“First there was his self-pity — everything was someone else’s fault — and then there was his self-will — no one must oppose him on anything at any time ever.”

I just finished reading Antonia Fraser’s 1994 book, The Wives of Henry VIII, and I found that description of King Henry VIII — he of the six wives, two beheaded, and the English Reformation) on page 336. I just had to share it with you.

But that’s an aside showing how our zeitgeist infects even my recreational reading. (It may also show more than you care to know about my idea of recreational reading, but I suppose that’s another story, too.)

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The substance of this post is about the cadence of meetings.

Cadence is a communications concept. If a group is working on a project, the group should meet frequently to make sure the group maintains its momentum. If a group does general oversight — the board of directors — then the group should meet less frequently.

The desire to set a cadence means, I fear, that people frequently set meetings for no reason at all.

“The appropriate cadence for this team to meet is once per month. That’s about enough for the nature of the work that the group performs.”

The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
What happens?

“Oh, my God! The next meeting in the cycle is set for this Wednesday! We had forgotten about that. We don’t have an agenda. Can anybody gin up a few speakers to talk about something that’s arguably relevant to the group so that we fill the time?”

That conversation is routine. You hear it before many, many meetings.  And it’s an admission of defeat: “We don’t really have anything to talk about, but we have to gin up irrelevant crap to fill the time.”

At the end of the meeting, of course, everyone will praise the meeting: “Great meeting! Good speakers! Glad we did it!” Praising the meeting is no skin off the attendees’ teeth, and it’s better for your career to praise meetings than to criticize them (or to say that the meetings were entirely unnecessary). But don’t ignore the truth, despite what people say: People (or at least the people you’d like to retain) couldn’t have helped noticing that there was no reason at all to hold the meeting, no one learned anything of importance, and everyone just lost an hour out of their day.

I’m not opposed to all meetings.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Sometimes you meet because a project demands that people discuss what’s happening. That’s an extraordinarily good reason for a meeting.

I don’t mind quarterly oversight meetings. If all the group is doing is oversight, then surely some things that require oversight have occurred in the prior three months.

Sometimes scheduling meetings regularly serves a purpose, even when the participants really have nothing to discuss: “We have 1,000 illegal contracts!  We’d better get them corrected pronto. We must assign someone to be responsible for this task, and we must then schedule weekly meetings between (1) the person responsible for the task and (2) a very important person in the firm, at which we’ll discuss the progress being made on the task.” Those meetings serve a purpose: The person doing the task understands that he’s under the gun and, more importantly, he understands that God is watching him. “God is watching” meetings serve a purpose, even if the job could be accomplished without them.

In a world when we’re allowed to meet in person, meetings can improve collegiality, even if the agenda is light.

But please consider canceling meetings when you realize that you have a meeting scheduled for next week and nothing to communicate. Canceling the meeting is an entirely legitimate alternative to burdening your audience with drivel because you have nothing to say.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](https://www.amazon.com/Curmudgeons-Guide-Practicing-Law-Second/dp/1641054344) and [Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strateg](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0)[y](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Early Mover On Biglaw Bonuses Is Back At It
## Top 20 firm is handing out even more money.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 17, 2021 at 1:58 PMMarch 24, 2022 at 11:20 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/&text=Early%20Mover%20On%20Biglaw%20Bonuses%20Is%20Back%20At%20It)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Back in the early days of December, Mayer Brown [announced ](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-bonus/)its year-end bonuses for associates. And, at least for associates in major markets, it was a match of the — then –prevailing market standard. However, the market has changed since then. Beginning with Davis Polk’s [announcement](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/davis-polk-biglaws-new-compensation-champion/) of additional special bonuses on top of the annual ones, the market standard increased since those early days.

And now Mayer Brown has matched those special bonuses, as per the below scale:



Unlike the first round of bonuses that had different scale for different offices, these special bonuses apply to all U.S. associates who meet their bonus hour threshold.

You can read the full memo [on the next page.](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/2/)

[*** Wondering if the grass is greener on the in-house side? Click here for a look inside the black box of corporate counsel pay in our 2021 In-House Compensation Report. ***](https://info.abovethelaw.com/2021-in-house-compensation-survey-report)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for all of your help!

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

1 [2](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/2/)[Next »](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/mayer-brown-specials-21/2/)
